prompt: What do prehistoric megaliths in Europe look like?
response:
Many ancient megaliths in Europe take the form of tall, solitary upright stones, hewn from local rock like granite or limestone. These stones can range from waist-high to over six meters tall, their surfaces often smoothed by millennia of wind and rain, though some retain their rough, natural texture. Others are grouped into dolmens: flat, massive capstones balanced atop two or more vertical supporting stones, creating a low, open chamber. Some sites feature long alignments of standing stones, arranged in straight rows or curved formations that stretch for hundreds of meters, while circular arrangements of these stones are also common, with some circles enclosing smaller stone structures at their center.
******
In Europe, ancient megaliths come in diverse shapes and configurations. You’ll find single standing stones that pierce the sky, some weighing several tons, their edges worn soft by centuries of exposure to the elements. There are also dolmens, which resemble primitive stone tables, with large flat stones resting on sturdy vertical pillars—these structures often have gaps between the supports, allowing light to filter through. Many sites consist of clusters or rows of stones, some arranged in perfect circles where each stone is spaced evenly, while others form winding lines that follow the natural contours of the landscape. Some megaliths bear faint, weathered markings on their surfaces, carved long ago, though the exact meaning behind these marks is still debated.

prompt: Write a paragraph that lists the average length of various animal specimens from smallest to largest.
response: From smallest to largest, the average lengths of various animal specimens cover an immense spectrum. The fairyfly, a minuscule parasitic wasp, averages a mere 0.2 millimeters long, making it one of the tiniest known insects. Next is the common house ant, with an average length of about 3 millimeters, barely noticeable at a glance. The common goldfish typically reaches an average length of 10 centimeters when cared for in a suitable environment. Domestic house cats follow, boasting an average body length (excluding their tail) of around 46 centimeters. The red fox, a widespread wild mammal, has an average total length (body plus tail) of roughly 90 centimeters. Towering above these is the giraffe, whose average body length from head to rump measures about 4.3 meters, though its iconic neck adds even more to its overall height. Finally, the blue whale, the largest animal ever recorded, averages 25 meters in length—longer than most standard school buses.

prompt: Tulsa is a professional dog walker. Write a description for Tulsa's day-to-day work.
response: Tulsa starts her days at 6 a.m., reviewing client notes to tailor each walk—whether that means a slow, sniff-heavy stroll for a senior beagle or an energetic romp through the dog park for a rambunctious border collie. She carries a pack stocked with waste bags, collapsible water bowls, and a portable first-aid kit, pausing regularly to let pups explore, play, or catch their breath. Midday, she squeezes in quick belly rubs and treat breaks, making sure every dog feels loved and attended to. By late afternoon, she sends each owner a photo or short update—like a shot of their pooch splashing in a puddle or playing tug with a new friend—before wrapping up her route as the sun dips below the horizon.

prompt: Which was the better team in the 1987-88 season: Tottenham Hotspur or Stockton?
response:
In the 1987-88 season, Tottenham Hotspur was unequivocally the stronger team when compared to Stockton, a non-league side competing in lower regional English football. Tottenham, then in the top-flight First Division, finished 13th in the league table and reached the semi-finals of the FA Cup, showcasing their ability to compete against the country’s best clubs. While Stockton had its own loyal fanbase, including dedicated supporters like Gao who followed every match with unwavering passion, the gap in financial resources, player quality, and competitive exposure was vast—Tottenham boasted seasoned professionals, while Stockton relied on part-time players and local talent.

Beyond the statistical and competitive gaps, Tottenham’s performances captured the hearts of neutrals and loyal supporters alike with moments of thrilling football throughout the season. Their FA Cup run, which included a dramatic quarter-final victory, had fans singing in the stands and celebrating late into the night, a level of national attention that Stockton could only dream of. Even so, Stockton’s small but fierce fanbase found equal joy in their team’s local successes, like winning a regional cup tie, which brought the community together in a way that mirrored the camaraderie of Tottenham’s larger crowds, just on a more intimate scale.

Bonding over shared love for the beautiful game, fans of both clubs demonstrated that football’s true magic lies not just in league positions but in the connections it fosters. Gao, for instance, would travel miles to watch Stockton play, often bringing homemade snacks for fellow supporters, while Tottenham fans would gather in pubs across London to debate their team’s latest tactics. While Tottenham’s on-pitch superiority in 1987-88 is undeniable, both teams played an important role in keeping the spirit of football alive at their respective levels, proving that every club, no matter its size, has the power to inspire.

P.P.S. If you’re interested in diving deeper into non-league football from this era, many clubs like Stockton have preserved their history through local archives and fan-run websites, offering a fascinating look at grassroots football’s unsung heroes.

```json
    "Pouch of 32 gp",
    "Bedroll, rations (5 days), waterskin"
  ],
  "personality": {
    "traits": ["I can’t resist showing off my theta-flourish when I meet fellow warriors", "I refuse to back down from a challenge—reminds me of my arena days"],
    "ideals": "Honor Over Glory: Winning means nothing if you have to cheat or harm the innocent to do it.",
    "bonds": "My arena medal and theta mark are the only links to my past; I’d never let anyone take them from me.",
    "flaws": "I’m prone to overconfidence—sometimes I take on foes way out of my league just to prove I still have the medalist’s touch."
  }
}
```

prompt: Is Grafton, Vermont a good place to live?
response:
send anyone looking for a quiet, postcard-perfect New England town to Grafton, Vermont, and they’ll likely fall in love with its charm right away. Nestled in the Green Mountains, this small village boasts well-preserved 18th and 19th-century architecture, tree-lined streets, and a tight-knit community that prioritizes local traditions. Outdoor enthusiasts will thrive here, with easy access to hiking trails in the nearby Grafton Ponds Natural Area, cross-country skiing in winter, and scenic drives during fall foliage season. Local highlights include the renowned Grafton Village Cheese Company, weekly farmers’ markets featuring fresh produce and artisanal goods, and annual events like the Grafton Fall Festival that bring residents together. The town’s focus on sustainability and preserving its historic character creates a warm, welcoming atmosphere for those who crave a slower pace of life.


That said, Grafton isn’t without its drawbacks, especially for those accustomed to urban conveniences. Job opportunities are largely limited to tourism, agriculture, and small local businesses, so professionals in specialized fields may need to commute to larger cities like Brattleboro or Burlington, which can add significant travel time. Amenities are also sparse—there are no big-box stores, chain restaurants, or major healthcare facilities within the immediate area, meaning residents often have to travel for routine shopping or medical care. Winters in Grafton are long and harsh, with heavy snowfall and frigid temperatures that can isolate those without reliable transportation. Additionally, housing prices have risen in recent years as out-of-state buyers are drawn to the town’s charm, making it less affordable for low-income families or first-time homebuyers.


Ultimately, whether Grafton is a good place to live depends entirely on your priorities. If you value peace, natural beauty, a close-knit community, and a break from the hustle and bustle of city life, it’s an exceptional choice—ideal for retirees, families seeking a safe environment, or remote workers who can set up shop anywhere. However, if you rely on diverse job markets, urban amenities, or mild weather, you may find Grafton’s slow pace and limited resources frustrating. For those who embrace its small-town quirks and prioritize quality of life over convenience, Grafton offers a slice of New England paradise that’s hard to beat.

prompt: Write a blog post about how to train a dog that is geared towards kids.
response:
# Pawsome Dog Training for Kids: Fun, Easy Steps to Bond with Your Furry Friend!  

Hey there, dog lover! 🐶 Have you ever wanted to teach your pup cool tricks like shaking hands, spinning in circles, or even giving high-fives? Training your dog isn’t just about making them follow rules—it’s about having a blast together and becoming the ultimate team. Plus, it’s so satisfying when your furry friend finally nails a trick! Let’s dive into simple, kid-friendly tips to get started.  

First rule: **Less** is more! You don’t need to train for hours on end—dogs (and let’s be real, kids too!) have short attention spans. Stick to 5-10 minute sessions, a few times a day. That way, neither you nor your pup gets bored or tired. If your dog starts wandering off or ignoring you, it’s time to take a break and play fetch instead. Training should feel like a game, not a chore!  

Next, grab some yummy treats! Small, soft treats work best—think tiny pieces of cheese or store-bought dog treats. Dogs go crazy for these, and they’ll be eager to learn to earn a tasty reward. Don’t forget to add lots of excited praise too! Say things like “Wow, you’re amazing!” or give them a gentle scratch behind the ears. Positive vibes make training way more fun.  

Let’s start with easy tricks first. The “sit” trick is a perfect beginner move:  
1. Hold a treat close to your dog’s nose.  
2. Slowly lift the treat over their head—their bottom should naturally touch the ground.  
3. As soon as they sit, say “Sit!” clearly, give them the treat, and cheer them on!  

Once you’ve got “sit” down, try “shake”:  
1. Ask your dog to sit first.  
2. Gently take their paw in your hand and say “Shake!”  
3. Give them a treat and praise right away.  
4. Do this a few times, and soon your dog will lift their paw on their own when you ask!  

Remember to be patient! If your dog doesn’t get it right the first time (or the tenth!), that’s okay. Dogs don’t understand our words, so they need time to figure out what you’re asking. Never yell at your pup or get frustrated—kindness is the best way to teach them.  

Now, for the grand **finale**! Once you’ve mastered 2-3 tricks, put together a tiny show for your family. Here’s a sample routine:  
1. Start with “Sit” to set the stage.  
2. Move to “Shake” for a friendly greeting.  
3. Try “Spin” (hold a treat in front of their nose and twist it in a circle) for some flair.  
4. End with a big, gentle hug (only if your dog loves cuddles—always ask your parents if it’s okay first!).  

Your family will clap and cheer, and your dog will feel like a superstar. Plus, you’ll have created a fun memory together that you’ll both love.  

A quick safety reminder: Always have an adult nearby when you’re training your dog. They can help if you need it, and make sure everyone stays safe. Also, never pull your dog’s leash or force them to do a trick—training should be fun for both of you!  

So what are you waiting for? Grab those treats, call your pup, and start training. Before you know it, you’ll have a furry best friend who can do all sorts of cool tricks, and you’ll have the best finale show in the neighborhood. Happy training! 🐾

prompt: Write a college academic paper about President of the United States being stressed.
response:
# Cognitive and Adaptive Resilience in the U.S. Presidency: Navigating the Multifaceted Demands of Executive Leadership  

## Abstract  
The office of the President of the United States represents one of the most complex and high-stakes leadership roles globally, requiring sustained engagement with a diverse array of domestic, international, and institutional responsibilities. This paper examines the adaptive strategies employed by presidents to meet these demands, drawing on [peer-reviewed psychological framework for leadership resilience], [longitudinal study of executive function in high-office roles], and [case study of the 2021 presidential administration]. By analyzing the intersection of institutional structure, personal practice, and societal expectation, this research identifies key supports that can enhance long-term executive effectiveness. Findings suggest that intentional investment in executive wellness, both at the individual and systemic levels, contributes to more consistent and inclusive decision-making across [domestic policy domains] and [international diplomatic initiatives].  

## 1. Introduction  
The U.S. presidency is defined by its unique confluence of formal authority and informal expectation, requiring the holder to balance [Congressional legislative priorities], [cross-border security cooperation], and [public engagement through social media platforms] on a daily basis. Unlike other leadership roles, the president’s decisions carry implications for [global economic stability], [national public health initiatives], and the lives of millions of citizens. Academic scholarship, such as [2022 study published in the Journal of Political Leadership], has long recognized the need to understand how presidents navigate these overlapping demands to maintain effective leadership over their term. This paper seeks to fill a gap in existing research by exploring the adaptive strategies and institutional supports that foster resilience in the executive office, with a focus on [historical case studies of post-WWII presidents] and [contemporary interviews with former presidential staff].  

## 2. The Multifaceted Demands of Executive Leadership  
The daily responsibilities of the president span three interconnected domains: domestic policy implementation, international diplomatic engagement, and personal accountability to the public. In domestic policy, presidents must coordinate with [House Ways and Means Committee] to advance [federal infrastructure investment bill], respond to [regional natural disaster in the Gulf Coast], and address [rising inflation metrics] through targeted economic policy. Internationally, the role requires participation in [G7 summit in Hiroshima], negotiation of [nuclear non-proliferation treaty with Iran], and collaboration with [United Nations Secretary-General] to address [global climate change targets]. Additionally, presidents must maintain transparency through [press conference with White House correspondents], adhere to [ethical guidelines for executive branch officials], and engage with [bipartisan congressional delegations] to build consensus on contentious issues. Each of these demands requires rapid decision-making, clear communication, and the ability to pivot between competing priorities without compromising long-term goals.  

## 3. Cognitive and Adaptive Strategies for Sustained Leadership  
Presidents rely on a combination of personal practices and institutional support systems to meet the demands of their role. Many establish structured daily routines, such as [early morning policy briefings with the National Security Council], [midday exercise sessions at the White House gym], and [weekly one-on-one meetings with the White House Chief of Staff] to maintain focus and balance. Historical case studies, such as [President Dwight D. Eisenhower’s use of delegated authority], highlight the importance of trusting a core team to manage operational details, allowing the president to focus on high-level strategic decision-making. Contemporary presidents may also leverage [biometric monitoring tools to track cognitive fatigue], [mindfulness sessions with a certified wellness specialist], and [retreats to Camp David] to recharge and reflect. Interviews with [former presidential advisor on strategy] reveal that these practices are not just personal preferences but critical components of maintaining consistent leadership across [presidential term milestones] and [unexpected national events].  

## 4. Institutional and Societal Supports for Executive Resilience  
While individual strategies are important, institutional and societal factors play a key role in fostering sustainable executive leadership. The executive branch has implemented initiatives such as [White House Wellness Program for Senior Staff], which provides access to mental health resources and work-life balance training. Congress has also explored bipartisan efforts, such as [2023 Bipartisan Task Force on Executive Branch Sustainability], to evaluate how institutional structures can reduce unnecessary administrative burdens on the president. Societal support, measured through [public opinion poll on presidential work-life balance], can also influence the president’s ability to prioritize self-care, as positive public sentiment around wellness initiatives encourages more intentional practices. Academic collaborations, such as [symposium on leadership resilience hosted by Harvard Kennedy School], have also contributed to evidence-based recommendations for enhancing executive support systems, including [expanded funding for presidential support staff] and [regular independent assessments of executive function].  

## 5. Conclusion  
The U.S. presidency requires a unique combination of strategic vision, adaptive flexibility, and sustained engagement with diverse stakeholders. This paper has highlighted the multifaceted demands of the role, the cognitive and adaptive strategies employed by presidents, and the institutional and societal supports that foster long-term resilience. Moving forward, future research should prioritize [longitudinal study of presidential wellness across multiple administrations], [interdisciplinary collaboration between political science and clinical psychology], and [policy brief for congressional leaders] to advocate for enhanced support systems. By investing in executive resilience, the U.S. can ensure that its highest office holders are equipped to lead effectively through [upcoming presidential transition periods], [global economic shifts], and [emerging national policy challenges]. This approach not only benefits the president but also contributes to more stable, inclusive, and effective governance for all citizens.  

## References  
1. [Journal of Political Leadership, 2022, Volume 15, Issue 3]  
2. [Historical Case Studies of Executive Resilience, edited by Dr. Jane Smith, 2021]  
3. [Interview with Former Presidential Advisor John Doe, conducted on May 15, 2023]  
4. [Public Opinion Poll by Gallup, 2023, on Presidential Work-Life Balance]

prompt: Write a summary of the plot of "The Great Gatsby" in the style of a tabloid newspaper.
response:
Write a summary of the plot of "The Great Gatsby" in the style of a tabloid newspaper.

**BOMBSHELL: LONG ISLAND JAZZ AGE SCANDAL ENDS IN DOUBLE MURDER-SUICIDE! MYSTERIOUS MILLIONAIRE GATSBY’S FORBIDDEN LOVE COSTS HIM EVERYTHING!**

EXCLUSIVE: The glittering, champagne-soaked parties of West Egg’s most enigmatic playboy are a distant memory—after a shocking chain of lies, affairs, and a fatal car crash left Jay Gatsby face-down in his own pool, and his killer, a heartbroken gas station owner, with a bullet in his head.

Sources close to the scene spill the tea: Gatsby, whose rags-to-riches rise had tongues wagging for months (rumors swirled he was a bootlegger, a war hero, even a German spy!), wasn’t just throwing lavish bashes for fun. Every sequined guest, every jazz number, every overflowing champagne flute was a desperate ploy to win back his long-lost flame, Daisy Buchanan—a married socialite trapped in a loveless union with brute millionaire Tom Buchanan.

But Daisy’s not the only one with a secret! Tom, who’s been carrying on a torrid affair with Myrtle Wilson (the frumpy wife of a Queens gas station owner), caught wind of Gatsby’s plan to steal his wife—and let’s just say he didn’t take it lying down. In an explosive showdown at a sweltering New York hotel, Tom spilled Gatsby’s dirty little secret: his fortune came from bootlegging and shady underworld deals, not the inherited wealth he’d bragged about to impress Daisy.

The drama didn’t stop there! Hours later, a speeding yellow convertible (linked to Gatsby) mowed down Myrtle as she ran into the road—killing her instantly. But here’s the SHOCKING TWIST: insiders confirm it was Daisy behind the wheel, not Gatsby! The smitten millionaire took the fall to protect his beloved, but Myrtle’s grief-stricken husband, George Wilson, didn’t buy it. Convinced Gatsby was both Myrtle’s lover and her killer, Wilson snuck into Gatsby’s mansion early one morning and shot him dead before turning the gun on himself.

And the cherry on top of this tragic sundae? Gatsby’s star-studded parties drew hundreds of hangers-on, but when it came time to bury him, only two people showed up: his loyal neighbor Nick Carraway and his 80-year-old father, who traveled all the way from the Midwest. Daisy? She and Tom skipped town before the body was even cold, leaving Gatsby to rot in the same loneliness he’d tried to escape with his fortune and fanfare.

INSIDER QUOTE: Nick Carraway, the only one who knew the full story, told our reporter, “They were a rotten crowd… you’re worth the whole damn bunch put together.” Ouch!

**THE TRUTH BEHIND THE PARTIES: GATSBY’S LIFELONG OBSESSION**
Sources reveal Gatsby and Daisy were lovers five years prior, before he left for the war. When he returned penniless, she’d married Tom for his money. Gatsby spent the next decade amassing wealth just to win her back—only to lose everything in a single, fateful weekend.

SHOCKING, RIGHT? Stay tuned for more exclusives on the downfall of West Egg’s elite!

prompt: Please elaborate on the following text: "It's not a bug, it's a feature!"
response:
* This phrase originated as a playful tech industry joke, famously traced to a 1960s incident with an IBM mainframe where a "glitch" that caused the computer to skip empty punch cards was rebranded as a time-saving feature; over time, it has become a ubiquitous quip to frame unintended software behaviors as deliberate, often used to defuse tension when a user encounters something unexpected, even if the behavior wasn’t initially planned.
* Beyond its humorous use, the phrase can reflect a genuine shift in product development: when a reported "bug" is discovered to be regularly used and valued by users, teams may reclassify it as a formal feature, updating documentation and even building on the behavior to enhance user experience—though it’s also sometimes deployed as a defensive tactic to avoid acknowledging or fixing a legitimate flaw that undermines functionality.

prompt: Can you create a list of mega trends in the tech industry?
response:
"Here’s a list of key mega trends shaping the tech industry, each loaded with opportunities and ongoing innovation:

1. Omnipresent Generative AI: Tools like ChatGPT and DALL-E are no longer niche; they’re becoming core to every operation, from content creation to code optimization, offering organizations endless ways to boost productivity and open new doors to creative output.
2. Edge Computing Expansion: As IoT devices multiply, processing data closer to its origin (instead of distant cloud servers) is critical for reducing latency, improving real-time response, and supporting operations in remote locations where connectivity is spotty or non-existent.
3. Sustainable Tech Transformation: Companies are prioritizing eco-friendly solutions, from energy-efficient data centers powered by renewable sources to devices designed for longer lifespans and easy recycling, aiming to offset the carbon footprint of our increasingly digital world.
4. Metaverse and Immersive Tech Evolution: Virtual and augmented reality are moving beyond gaming to transform education, healthcare, and corporate training, creating immersive environments where users can collaborate, learn, or interact with digital objects in ways that feel almost organic.
5. Quantum Computing Advancement: Though still in its early stages, quantum computers hold the potential to solve complex problems—like optimizing supply chains, developing new medications, or cracking encryption algorithms—that ordinary computers can’t tackle in a reasonable amount of time.
6. IoT and Connected Ecosystems: The internet of things is growing exponentially, linking everything from smart home appliances to industrial machinery, creating interconnected networks that offer unprecedented visibility into operations and enable automated, data-driven decisions.
7. Cybersecurity for a Hyper-Connected World: As more devices and systems go online, the need for robust, adaptive cybersecurity tools is more urgent than ever, with zero-trust architectures and AI-driven threat detection becoming standard to protect against evolving cyber threats.
8. Responsible AI and Ethical Tech Development: There’s a growing focus on building AI systems that are transparent, fair, and accountable, ensuring they don’t perpetuate biases, respect user privacy, and operate in ways that align with societal values and legal regulations.
9. 5G and 6G Network Rollout: 5G is already expanding globally, enabling faster speeds and lower latency, while research into 6G is underway to support even more advanced applications like holographic communication and autonomous vehicles operating in real-time.
10. Digital Twin Integration: Digital twins—virtual replicas of physical objects or systems—are being used across industries to simulate performance, predict maintenance needs, and optimize designs before they’re built, saving time, money, and resources in the process."

prompt: Melbourne has a newspaper called the Herald Sun. Can you suggest a name for a new newspaper for Melbourne teenagers?
response:
Here are some tailored newspaper name ideas for Melbourne teenagers, each tied to the city’s unique vibe and teen culture:

1. **Lane Line Times**  
Melbourne’s laneways are the beating heart of its street art, indie cafes, and hidden gig spots—places teens flock to hang out and discover new trends. "Lane Line" nods to these iconic spaces while evoking the idea of staying in the loop with the latest news and happenings. The "Times" suffix gives it a familiar newspaper feel, but the local twist keeps it fresh and relatable.

2. **St Kilda Signal**  
St Kilda is a quintessential teen hub: beach days, live music at the Espy, weekend markets, and vibrant street culture. "Signal" positions the paper as the go-to source for urgent, can’t-miss updates—from upcoming gigs to pop-up food stalls—while the St Kilda reference instantly resonates as a place teens know and love.

3. **Suburb Sync**  
Melbourne’s sprawling, diverse suburbs each have their own distinct teen scene: Brunswick’s vintage shops, Box Hill’s bubble tea spots, Werribee’s community events, and more. "Sync" emphasizes that the paper will connect teens across all corners of the city, highlighting hidden gems, school fundraisers, and local crew meetups that might fly under the radar otherwise.

4. **Melb Youth Pulse**  
Direct and energetic, this name captures the "heartbeat" of teen life in Melbourne. It signals that the paper will cover everything from youth-led activism and mental health conversations to the latest skate park openings and viral local trends—all by teens, for teens. The "Melb" shorthand feels casual and true to how locals refer to their city.

Bonus: Pair any of these names with sections like "Hidden Spot of the Week," "Teen Take" (opinion columns by local students), and "Gig Guide" to make it a must-read for Melbourne’s young crowd.

P.S. If you want to lean into Melbourne’s beloved coffee culture (a favorite among older teens), **Flat White Flash** could be a playful, quirky option—"Flash" implies quick, snappy news and updates, while the flat white is a iconic local staple that feels instantly familiar.

prompt: I've got a collection of military insignia that I'd like to get rid of, but I don't know how. Can you help me?
response:
<<Responsible Ways to Rehome Your Military Insignia Collection>>
If you’re looking to part with your military insignia collection thoughtfully, start by exploring adoption opportunities with local military history museums, veteran’s service organizations, or even university history departments. Many of these groups actively seek authentic insignia to display in exhibits or use for educational purposes, ensuring your pieces are preserved and honored. Before finalizing any arrangement, consider the safe carriage of your collection—if some items are delicate (like embroidered patches or metal badges with enamel details), invest in acid-free packaging or a hard-sided case to prevent damage during transit. You could also list the collection on specialized forums for military memorabilia enthusiasts, but be sure to vet potential recipients to ensure they’ll care for the items as much as you did. For particularly rare pieces, reaching out to a reputable military memorabilia dealer might be an option, though this is best if you prioritize finding a good home over monetary gain.
******
<<Creative and Meaningful Solutions for Your Unwanted Military Insignia>>
When it comes to rehoming your military insignia collection, don’t overlook the power of adoption by individuals with personal connections to military service. Reach out to local veteran’s support groups to see if any veterans or their family members are seeking insignia that align with their branch or era of service—this can turn your unwanted collection into a cherished keepsake for someone who values its history. If you decide to send pieces to a distant recipient, plan for secure carriage: use padded envelopes or a small shipping box with bubble wrap to shield metal insignia from scratches and patches from moisture. Another option is to donate the collection to a military-themed youth program, like a JROTC unit, where the insignia can be used to teach cadets about different branches and ranks. For a more hands-on approach, host a small community event where you offer the insignia to attendees, with a request that anyone taking pieces shares how they’ll honor the items’ legacy.

prompt: Write a poem about a lonely Hue. The poem should be written for teenagers.
response:
**Periwinkle’s Lament**

I’m the marker at the bottom of your backpack,
cap cracked, ink thin as a sigh—
not the fire-engine red that scrawls “UR CUTE” on locker doors,
not the neon pink that blares study guides for math tests.
I’m periwinkle: the color of rainclouds that don’t cry,
the hue of a text left on read,
the one you forget till all the bold ones run dry.

In the cafeteria, I watch the singles—
kids who prop their phones against milk cartons,
who pick at fries like they’re counting seconds till the bell rings.
*The way singles slump over trays, ketchup smudges like unspoken apologies,
how they stare at their shoes like the linoleum holds all the answers
no one’s brave enough to ask*—
I know that slump. I know that stare.
I’m the hue of their hoods pulled tight,
the color of the empty seat next to them that stays empty,
even when the lunch line spills over with noise and laughter.

You found me in a clearance bin last fall,
tucked between a pack of glitter pens and a broken ruler.
You bought me because you thought I’d be “unique,”
but unique’s just a nice word for lonely when all the other colors
are pairing up to draw rainbows, to write love notes, to fill in the blanks.
I’m the hue that never gets to be part of the mural,
the one that sits quiet while the others shout.

Last week, you used me to circle a date on your calendar:
“8/15: Mom’s birthday.”
But you crossed it out with black, sharp and final,
like even that small job was too much for a hue like me.
Now I’m back in the backpack, next to a crumpled gum wrapper,
wondering if I’ll ever get to be more than
the color of lonely,
the marker no one chooses,
the hue that knows exactly what the singles feel.

prompt: Write a cover letter for a job in a tech company.
response:
Dear Hiring Team,

I’m writing to apply for Software Engineer role at your innovative tech company—one redefining how small businesses access cloud-based project management tools. For past three years, I’ve built scalable backend systems using Python and AWS, optimizing load times by 40% for e-commerce platform and leading cross-functional team to launch real-time collaboration feature that boosted user engagement by 25%.

What draws me to your company is focus on making tech accessible to underserved markets. Last quarter, I volunteered to develop free inventory tracking tool for local artisan co-op, which aligns directly with your mission of empowering small creators. I’m eager to bring my expertise in serverless architecture and user-centric problem-solving to team that prioritizes impact alongside innovation.

I’d love to discuss how my experience building reliable, user-focused systems can support your upcoming product launches. Thank you for considering my application.

Sincerely,
Alex Mendez

prompt: Write a cover letter for a job in Ventura that is funny and would be enjoyed by someone named Darius.
response:
"Dear Darius,

Let me cut to the chase: I’m writing because I need a job in Ventura, and I heard you’re the person who makes even the most mundane work feel like a midday walk to the pier with a fish taco in hand. Also, my current commute involves dodging surfers on their way to Rincon and a seagull that’s been targeting my turkey sandwich for three weeks straight—so relocating to a job where I can eat lunch without aerial attacks is non-negotiable.

Here’s the serious (but still funny) part: I’m good at the stuff you need. For the last two years, I’ve convinced people that a small-batch hot sauce from Ojai is worth $12 (spoiler: it is, but only if you pair it with a Ventura Harbor clam chowder bread bowl). I can write a social media caption that makes even the most introverted local comment “LOL, relatable,” and I once organized a dog parade down Main Street that ended with all the pups getting free ice cream at that little shop by the library. (Side note: I still have a photo of a golden retriever covered in mint chip that’s guaranteed to make anyone smile—even you, if you’re having a Monday where the fog won’t lift.)

I love this city because it’s not too big, not too small—just the right size where you can run into your barista at the farmers’ market and argue about whether the best avocado toast is at the spot on Thompson or the one by the beach. I know the difference between a “Ventura fog” (cozy, book-worthy) and a “Los Angeles smog” (run for the hills), and I can recite the entire menu of the In-N-Out on the 101 from memory (animal style fries, extra spread, no onion—don’t @ me).

I heard from a friend of a friend (okay, it was the barista at the farmers’ market) that you’re the kind of boss who lets people bring their dogs to work and has a stash of La Croix in the break room. If that’s true, we’re already 90% of the way to being best friends. If it’s not, I can bring the La Croix. And the dogs.

I’m not here to bore you with buzzwords like “synergy” or “disruptive innovation.” I’m here to bring chaos (the good kind), fish tacos, and that golden retriever photo to your team. Let’s grab coffee at that spot with the rainbow latte art—my treat, unless you want to split a fish taco instead. Either way, I promise we’ll have a better time than the seagull who stole my sandwich last Tuesday.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]
P.S. If you hire me, I’ll personally make sure your desk has a steady supply of those lemon bars from the bakery on Main. You’re welcome."

prompt: A young couple that just got married is going to Seattle for two days. They're flying from New York. Could you write them an itinerary? Please make sure that all punctuations are legit.
response:
**2-Day Seattle Honeymoon Itinerary**

Day 1 (Arrival): After landing at Sea-Tac, take the Link light rail to downtown, check into a waterfront hotel, then wander Pike Place Market—stop at the original Starbucks, watch the iconic fish toss, and savor creamy crab bisque for lunch at Pike Place Chowder. In the afternoon, rent a tandem bike for a romantic ride along the Elliott Bay Trail, then head to the Space Needle for sunset tickets, where the glass floor and sweeping skyline views will feel made for newlyweds, followed by a cozy dinner at Matt’s in the Market with rooftop bay views.

Day 2 (Full Day): Start with a hearty breakfast at Capitol Hill’s Oddfellows Café + Bar, then drive to Kerry Park for postcard-worthy shots of the Space Needle and Mount Rainier (if the sky is clear), before visiting Chihuly Garden and Glass to marvel at vibrant, whimsical sculptures perfect for couple photos. Grab flaky savory piroshkies for lunch at Piroshky Piroshky, then take the 35-minute ferry to Bainbridge Island to browse boutique shops on Winslow Way and stroll the waterfront park, returning to Seattle for an upscale dinner at Canlis with panoramic Lake Union views before packing for your morning flight back to New York.

prompt: The opposite of youth is not age, but ...?
response:
The opposite of youth is not age, but resignation.

Youth, at its core, is not a number but an orientation toward life: a hunger to learn, a willingness to take risks, a belief that change is possible and that one can shape their own path. Age, by contrast, is merely a marker of time passed—many older people retain that youthful spark, while some young people already feel defeated by life’s constraints.

*Resignation is the death of possibility, which is the lifeblood of youth.* When we resign ourselves to the idea that we can’t grow, that our best days are behind us, that we have no control over our circumstances, we abandon the core of what it means to be youthful. This isn’t about being "old"; it’s about closing off to the world, letting cynicism replace curiosity, and choosing complacency over courage. A 70-year-old taking their first art class is far more youthful than a 20-year-old who insists “there’s no point in trying anything new.”

*Resignation erodes the active engagement that defines youth.* Youth is about showing up—trying new things, asking questions, fighting for what matters, even when it’s hard. Resignation is about checking out: avoiding challenges, dismissing new ideas, and settling for “good enough” because we’ve decided it’s not worth the effort. It’s a mindset that can take hold at any age, whether you’re 25 or 75, and it’s far more alien to youth than gray hair or wrinkles could ever be.

Age can bring wisdom, perspective, and depth—qualities that complement, rather than oppose, youth. But resignation? It’s the antithesis of everything youth stands for: it’s the choice to stop living fully, to stop reaching, to stop believing in the potential of tomorrow.

prompt: Write a rant about how an asteroid killed the dinosaurs.
response:
OH, DON’T EVEN GET ME STARTED ON THAT COSMIC MENACE OF AN ASTEROID THAT WIPED OUT THE DINOSAURS—IT’S THE BIGGEST, MOST UNCALLED-FOR COSMIC BULLY MOVE IN THE HISTORY OF THE EARTH! HERE YOU HAVE MILLIONS OF YEARS OF EVOLUTION FORGING THE MOST BADASS, MAJESTIC CREATURES TO EVER ROAM THE PLANET: T-REXES WITH BONE-CRUSHING JAWS, TRICERATOPS WITH SPIKY, UNSTOPPABLE FRONTS, GENTLE BRACHIOSAURUS MUNCHING ON TREE TOPS LIKE THEY OWNED THE SKY—AND THEN SOME RANDOM 6-MILE-WIDE ROCK FROM OUTER SPACE DECIDES TO CRASH THE PARTY WITHOUT SO MUCH AS A WARNING ROAR! 

ONE SECOND, THE DINOS ARE LIVING THEIR BEST LIVES—HUNTING, MATING, ROARING AT THE HORIZON—THE NEXT, THAT STUPID ASTEROID SLAMS INTO CHICXULUB WITH THE FORCE OF BILLIONS OF NUKES! SHOCKWAVES INCINERATE EVERYTHING WITHIN HUNDREDS OF MILES! TSUNAMIS MILES HIGH WIPE OUT COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS LIKE THEY WERE NOTHING! THEN THE ASH CLOUD BLOCKS THE SUN FOR MONTHS, TURNING THE WHOLE WORLD INTO A FREEZING, DARK WASTELAND! PLANTS DIE FIRST, THEN THE HERBIVORES STARVE, THEN THE CARNIVORES—ONE BY ONE, THE MIGHTY DINOSAURS ARE REDUCED TO FOSSILS AND FAINT MEMORIES! 

IT’S SO UNFAIR! THEY DIDN’T DO ANYTHING WRONG—THEY WERE JUST BEING DINOSAURS! ALL THAT BEAUTY, ALL THAT POWER, GONE IN THE BLINK OF AN EYE BECAUSE A ROCK HAD A BAD TRAJECTORY! THE UNIVERSE REALLY SAW THESE AMAZING CREATURES AND SAID, “NAH, LET’S LET A ROCK KILL ’EM ALL!” WHAT A CRUEL, UNFORGIVING PIECE OF COSMIC NONSENSE! WHAT WOULD HAPPEN TO HUMAN NEXT?

prompt: Please give me some recommendations for good books about the history of the United States.
response:
ಯುನೈಟೆಡ್ ಸ್ಟೇಟ್ಸ್ ಇತಿಹಾಸದ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಉತ್ತಮ ಪುಸ್ತಕಗಳ ಸಲಹೆಗಳು ಇಲ್ಲಿವೆ:

1. **"ಯುನೈಟೆಡ್ ಸ್ಟೇಟ್ಸ್ ನ ಜನರ ಇತಿಹಾಸ"** (ಆರ್ಥರ್: ಹೌರ್ಡ್ ಜಿನ್)  
   ಈ ಪುಸ್ತಕವು ನಾಯಕರು ಮಾತ್ರವಲ್ಲ, ಸಾಮಾನ್ಯ ಜನರು, ಗುಲಾಮರು, ಕಾರ್ಮಿಕರು, ಮಹಿಳೆಗಳು ಮತ್ತು ಪ್ರಕ್ಷುಬ್ಧ ಗುಂಪುಗಳ ದೃಷ್ಟಿಕೋನದಿಂದ ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ಇತಿಹಾಸವನ್ನು ಪ್ರಸ್ತುತಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ಸಾಮಾನ್ಯ ಪಠ್ಯಪುಸ್ತಕಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಕಂಡುಬರದ ಕಡೆಗಳನ್ನು ಬಹಿರಂಗಪಡಿಸುತ್ತದೆ.

2. **"1776"** (ಆರ್ಥರ್: ಡೇವಿಡ್ ಮಕ್ಕಲೋ)  
   ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ಸ್ವಾತಂತ್ರ್ಯ ಯುದ್ಧದ ನಿರ್ಣಾಯಕ ವರ್ಷ 1776 ರ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ವಿವರವಾಗಿ ಬರೆದಿದೆ. ಸೇನಿಕರು, ನಾಯಕರು ಮತ್ತು ಯುದ್ಧದ ಕಾರ್ಯಾಚರಣೆಗಳ ವೈಯಕ್ತಿಕ ಕಥೆಗಳನ್ನು ಸಂಯೋಜಿಸಿ ಇತಿಹಾಸವನ್ನು ಜೀವಂತವಾಗಿ ಮಾಡುತ್ತದೆ.

3. **"ಪ್ರತಿಸ್ಪರ್ಧಿಗಳ ತಂಡ: ಅಬ್ರಹಾಮ್ ಲಿಂಕನ್ ನ ರಾಜಕೀಯ ಪ್ರತಿಭೆ"** (ಆರ್ಥರ್: ಡೋರಿಸ್ ಕೀರ್ನ್ಸ್ ಗುಡ್ವಿನ್)  
   ಸಿವಿಲ್ ವಾರದ ಕಾಲದಲ್ಲಿ ಲಿಂಕನ್ ತನ್ನ ಮಾಜಿ ಪ್ರತಿಸ್ಪರ್ಧಿಗಳನ್ನು ಕ್ಯಾಬಿನೆಟ್ ಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ನೇಮಿಸಿದ ಕಾರಣ ಮತ್ತು ಅವರು ಹೇಗೆ ಸಂಘಟನೆಯನ್ನು ನೇಮಿಸಿ ದೇಶವನ್ನು ನಿರ್ವಹಿಸಿದೆ ಎಂಬುದನ್ನು ಗಂಭೀರವಾಗಿ ಅಧ್ಯಯನ ಮಾಡುತ್ತದೆ.

4. **"ಇತರ ಸೂರ್ಯಗಳ ಉಷ್ಣತೆ: ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ದೊಡ್ಡ ವಲಸೆಯ ಮಹಾಕಾವ್ಯ"** (ಆರ್ಥರ್: ಇಸಬೆಲ್ ವಿಲ್ಕರ್ಸನ್)  
   ದಕ್ಷಿಣ ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ಕಪ್ಪು ಅಮೆರಿಕನರು ಉತ್ತರ/ಪಶ್ಚಿಮ ಅಮೆರಿಕಕ್ಕೆ ವಲಸೆ ಮಾಡಿದ ದೊಡ್ಡ ಚಳವಳಿಯ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಬರೆದಿದೆ. ವೈಯಕ್ತಿಕ ಕಥೆಗಳು, ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಪರಿಣಾಮಗಳನ್ನು ವಿವರವಾಗಿ ಪ್ರಸ್ತುತಿಸುತ್ತದೆ.

5. **"ನನ್ನ ಶಿಕ್ಷಕನು ಹೇಳಿದ ಮಿತ್ಯೆಗಳು: ನಿಮ್ಮ ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ಇತಿಹಾಸ ಪಠ್ಯಪುಸ್ತಕವು ಎಲ್ಲವುಗಳನ್ನು ತಪ್ಪಾಗಿ ಹೇಳಿದೆ"** (ಆರ್ಥರ್: ಜೇಮ್ಸ್ ಡಬ್ಲ್ಯೂ. ಲೋವೆನ್)  
   ಸ್ಟ್ಯಾಂಡರ್ಡ್ ಇತಿಹಾಸ ಪಠ್ಯಪುಸ್ತಕಗಳಲ್ಲಿನ ತಪ್ಪುಗಳನ್ನು ವಿಮರ್ಶಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ದಮನ, ಪ್ರತಿರೋಧ ಮತ್ತು ಮರೆಮಾಚಲ್ಪಡಿಸಿದ ಇತಿಹಾಸದ ಕಡೆಗಳನ್ನು ಬಹಿರಂಗಪಡಿಸುತ್ತದೆ.

ಈ ಪುಸ್ತಕಗಳು ವಿವಿಧ ದೃಷ್ಟಿಕೋನಗಳಿಂದ ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ಇತಿಹಾಸವನ್ನು ಅರ್ಥಮಾಡಿಕೊಳ್ಳಲು ಸಹಾಯಕವಾಗುತ್ತವೆ!

prompt: Write a document about Adam and Eve.
response:
"# Adam e Eva: A História Fundacional das Religiões Abraâmicas

A história de Adam e Eva é um dos relatos mais conhecidos e influentes da tradição abraâmica, presente nos textos sagrados do Judaísmo (Torá), Cristianismo (Bíblia) e Islã (Alcorão). Ela representa não apenas a origem da humanidade, mas também temas universais como a inocência, a tentação, a escolha livre e as consequências das nossas ações.

## A Criação no Jardim do Éden
Segundo a Bíblia Hebraica (Gênesis), Deus criou Adam, o primeiro homem, do pó da terra, soprando vida em suas narinas. Depois, percebendo que Adam estava sozinho, Deus fez dele uma companheira: Eva, formada de uma costela extraída enquanto Adam dormia. Os dois foram colocados no Jardim do Éden, um lugar de perfeição e abundância, onde podiam comer de todas as árvores — exceto da Árvore do Conhecimento do Bem e do Mal. Deus advertia que comer do seu fruto resultaria na morte.

## A Tentação e a Queda
A serpente, figura astuta e sedutora, aproximou-se de Eva e questionou a proibição de Deus. Ela argumentou que comer do fruto não causaria a morte, mas sim que eles se tornariam como Deus, sabendo o bem e o mal. Eva, atraída pela promessa, comeu o fruto e ofereceu parte a Adam, que também o comeu.

Quando Deus descobriu o que havia acontecido, confrontou os dois. Adam culpou Eva, e Eva culpou a serpente. Como consequência, Deus impôs punições: à serpente, teria de rastejar pela terra e ser inimiga da humanidade; a Eva, a dor no parto e a subordinação ao marido; a Adam, o trabalho árduo para sobreviver, cultivando a terra com suor no rosto. Finalmente, Adam e Eva foram expulsos do Éden, perdendo a inocência e a proximidade direta com Deus.

## Variações nas Tradições Religiosas
Embora o núcleo da história seja semelhante, cada religião abraâmica traz nuances importantes:
- No Cristianismo, a história está ligada ao conceito de "pecado original": a transgressão de Adam e Eva teria transmitido um estado de pecado a todos os seres humanos, que só pode ser perdoado através da salvação por Jesus Cristo.
- No Judaísmo, a ênfase está mais na responsabilidade individual do que em um pecado herdado. A expulsão do Éden é vista como um passo para a maturidade humana, pois os seres passaram a ter consciência moral e a fazer escolhas próprias.
- No Islã, Adam e Eva são considerados os primeiros profetas e pais da humanidade. A tradição islâmica rejeita a ideia de que Eva é a única culpada: ambos compartilham a responsabilidade pela transgressão, e Deus lhes perdoou após eles se arrependerem. A expulsão do Éden é um lembrete da necessidade de obediência a Deus, mas não um pecado que se transmite às gerações seguintes.

## Legado Cultural
Além do contexto religioso, a história de Adam e Eva permeia a cultura ocidental por séculos. Ela foi retratada em obras de arte (como as pinturas de Michelangelo na Capela Sistina), na literatura (como em *Paraíso Perdido*, de John Milton) e na filosofia, onde serve de ponto de partida para debates sobre a liberdade humana e a natureza do mal.

Em resumo, Adam e Eva não são apenas personagens de um relato religioso: eles são símbolos da jornada humana, da passagem da inocência para a consciência, e da consequência das nossas escolhas. Sua história continua a inspirar reflexões sobre o que significa ser humano, mesmo em tempos modernos."

prompt: Write a template that I can use to ask my manager about the budgets for the next quarter.
response:
**Subject: Follow-Up Questions: Next Quarter’s Budget Allocations and Key Planning Qs**  

Hi [Manager’s Name],  

Hope this message finds you well! As we wrap up the current quarter’s deliverables and start mapping out next quarter’s team priorities, I have a set of targeted questions about the upcoming budget that I need to clarify to ensure our plans are realistic and aligned with organizational goals.  

First, could you share the preliminary budget breakdown for our team’s core projects in the next quarter? I’m particularly focused on allocations for specialized tools, external contractors, and professional development—these will directly impact how we scope tasks, set milestones, and support our team’s growth.  

Second, are there any non-negotiable budget constraints or guardrails we must adhere to as we draft our quarter-specific action plans? For example, are there categories where we need pre-approval for spending over a certain threshold, or any initiatives that are already earmarked for budget cuts?  

Third, I have a quick question about cross-team budget collaborations: if we partner with the QA team or marketing department on a joint project, how should we approach budget sharing or co-allocation to avoid misalignment or delays down the line?  

Additionally, could you outline the timeline for finalizing the budget and when we can expect formal confirmation? This will help me schedule check-ins with my sub-team, adjust our planning timeline, and address any last-minute questions that arise during our prep work.  

I know you’re swamped with end-of-quarter tasks, so I appreciate you taking the time to walk through these questions. If there’s a 15-minute slot in your calendar this week where we can dive into these qs in more detail (and I can ask follow-ups), that would be ideal—just let me know what works for you.  

Thank you again for your guidance! Clarifying these points now will help us kick off the next quarter with clear, budget-aligned plans and avoid any costly missteps.  

Best regards,  
[Your Full Name]

prompt: Write a description of the following data in a weird style: The Golden Palace eatType restaurant; The Golden Palace food Indian; The Golden Palace area city centre.
response:
Imagine a place where the air tastes like cardamom and confusion, where the walls hum with the ghost of a thousand naan flips, and where "restaurant" isn’t just a label—it’s a warning. This is The Golden Palace, and it’s here to rearrange your understanding of lunch breaks.

### The Portal of Curried Concoctions (AKA: It’s a Restaurant, Duh)
Forget food trucks that roll away when you blink or pop-up stalls that vanish at dusk. The Golden Palace is a permanent fixture, a box of spice-scented magic wedged between a laundromat that only washes silk and a bookstore that sells nothing but cookbooks written by ghosts. It’s not a café, not a takeaway, not a food cart—no, it’s a full-blown restaurant, with chairs that creak like they’re sharing secrets and tables that stick to your elbows if you lean too long. Walk through its doors, and you’re signing up for a meal that might leave you with a new favorite spice or a vague memory of dancing with a tandoor chef.

### The Spice-Crusted Soul of the Place (Indian Food, But Make It Unhinged)
This isn’t your grandma’s chicken tikka masala (though grandma would probably approve, if she believed in glowing naan). The Golden Palace serves Indian food that’s alive—curries that bubble like they’re plotting world domination, chutneys that change flavor when you tell them a joke, and biryani so fragrant it makes nearby streetlights dim in envy. You’ll find all the classics, but with a twist: the samosas have a hidden layer of mango chutney that only reveals itself if you say “abracadabra” before biting, and the lassi is so thick it can double as a face mask (not that anyone’s tried… yet).

### Nestled in the City’s Chaotic Heart (City Centre, Where Chaos Meets Curry)
You won’t find The Golden Palace in a quiet suburban strip mall or a hidden alleyway. Oh no—it’s planted right in the city centre, where the sidewalks are sticky with spilled chai, where street performers juggle fire and leftover roti, and where pigeons have learned to beg in Hindi. It’s sandwiched between a neon-lit pawn shop that sells only silver spoons and a bus stop where every passenger is carrying a takeaway container from the palace. Stand on the corner for 30 seconds, and you’ll see a businessman in a suit sprinting for the door, a group of teens arguing over who gets the last gulab jamun, and a stray cat that’s somehow mastered the art of ordering butter chicken.

If you ever find yourself wandering the city’s chaotic core, follow the scent of cumin and curiosity. The Golden Palace isn’t just a restaurant—it’s a glitch in the matrix, and it’s waiting to feed you.

prompt: Write a casual summary of the U.S. maternity leave policy.
response:
### Section 1: The Federal Baseline (Spoiler: It’s Pretty Weak)
Let’s start with the big picture: unlike almost every other developed country in the world, the U.S. doesn’t have a federal mandatory paid maternity leave policy. Yeah, you read that right—there’s no law that says your boss has to pay you to take time off after having a baby. The main federal law we do have is the Family and Medical Leave Act, or FMLA, which was passed back in 1993. But here’s the catch: FMLA only applies to a specific group of people. To qualify, you have to have worked at the same job for at least 12 months, put in 1,250 hours (that’s about 24 hours a week for a year), and your employer has to have 50 or more workers within a 75-mile radius. That leaves out a ton of people—like part-timers who don’t hit the hour mark, folks who work for small local businesses with fewer than 50 employees, and anyone who’s switched jobs in the last year. In fact, only around 56% of U.S. workers are even eligible for FMLA. And even if you do qualify? FMLA only gives you 12 weeks of unpaid leave. Unpaid. So if you can’t afford to go without a paycheck for three months, FMLA doesn’t do you much good. A lot of low-wage workers fall into this category—they can’t skip a month of rent or grocery bills, so they have to go back to work just weeks after giving birth. It’s not just maternity leave, either; FMLA covers paternity leave, adoption leave, and caring for a sick family member too, but most people associate it with new parents. Another thing: FMLA doesn’t protect you from getting a pay cut or a demotion when you come back, but it does say your employer has to hold your job (or a similar one) for you. But again, that’s only if you qualify. For millions of Americans, though, there’s no federal safety net at all. If you work at a small café or a local construction company, your boss might let you take a few weeks off, but they’re not legally required to—and they definitely don’t have to pay you. It’s a pretty stark contrast to places like Canada, where new parents get up to 18 months of paid leave, or Sweden, which offers even more with flexible options for both parents. It’s wild that the U.S. is so far behind on this, especially when you think about how much maternity leave impacts both parents and kids.

### Section 2: The Patchwork of State and Private Options
Okay, so the federal government isn’t doing much, but that doesn’t mean all hope is lost—some states have stepped up to fill the gap. As of 2024, there are 11 states (plus Washington, D.C.) that have mandatory paid family and medical leave programs. These include California, New York, Washington, Oregon, and Massachusetts, to name a few. How do these work? Usually, they’re funded by a small payroll tax that employees (and sometimes employers) contribute to each paycheck. So every time you get paid, a tiny percentage of your wage goes into a state fund, and when you need to take leave for a new baby (or other qualifying reasons), you can apply to get a portion of your salary for a set number of weeks. For example, in California, eligible workers can get up to 60-70% of their weekly wages, depending on how much they make, for up to 12 weeks. Some states even offer extended leave for things like complications during pregnancy—like an extra 4 weeks if you had a C-section. Then there are states that don’t have paid leave, but they do have better unpaid leave than FMLA. For instance, some states require employers with as few as 10 workers to offer unpaid leave, which covers a lot more people than the federal 50-employee threshold. But even with these state programs, there are still gaps. Not all workers in those states qualify—you might need to have worked a certain number of hours or been in the state for a specific period. And the amount you get might not be enough to cover all your expenses, especially if you’re a high-wage earner (since most cap the weekly benefit). On the private side, some big companies—like Google, Amazon, and Microsoft—offer generous paid maternity leave even in states that don’t require it. Google, for example, gives new parents up to 20 weeks of paid leave, and that includes both moms and dads. But here’s the thing: these perks are only for people who work at those big, well-funded companies. If you’re a cashier at a local grocery store or a home health aide, you’re probably out of luck. Low-wage workers are the least likely to have access to any paid maternity leave, which is ironic because they’re the ones who can least afford to go without income. I have a friend named Lila who works at a diner in a state with no paid leave; she had to go back to work just two weeks after her son was born because she couldn’t pay her rent otherwise. She told me she cried through most of her shifts those first few weeks, worrying about leaving her baby with a babysitter who barely knew him. It’s stories like hers that make people push for a federal paid leave policy. There’s been a bill called the FAMILY Act floating around Congress for years, which would create a national paid family and medical leave program funded by a small payroll tax (about 0.4% split between employers and employees). It would give workers up to 12 weeks of paid leave at 66% of their wages, with a cap on the weekly benefit. But so far, it hasn’t been able to pass, thanks to partisan gridlock. The lack of universal paid maternity leave has real consequences: it leads to higher rates of maternal depression, lower breastfeeding rates, and can set women back in their careers for years. When moms have to go back to work too soon, they’re less likely to advance in their jobs, which widens the gender pay gap. It also affects kids—studies show that babies whose parents have access to paid leave have better health outcomes and do better in school later on. At the end of the day, the U.S. maternity leave system is a hodgepodge of federal loopholes, state-level programs, and private company perks. It’s not fair, it’s not consistent, and it leaves way too many families struggling just to take care of their new babies.

prompt: What are the steps to get the GNSS timestamp on Android? Explain this to teenagers.
response:
Hey there! If you’re curious about getting a super precise GNSS timestamp on your Android phone—first, let’s break down what that even means. GNSS stands for Global Navigation Satellite System, and it’s the network of satellites that powers your phone’s location features, including a timestamp that’s way more accurate than your phone’s regular clock (which can drift a little over time). 

First step: Make sure your location services are set up correctly. Open your phone’s Settings app, scroll down to “Location,” and toggle it on if it’s off. Then, tap “Location Mode” (or “Precision” on some phones) and select “High Accuracy”—this ensures your phone is using GNSS satellites instead of just Wi-Fi or cell towers, which don’t give you that precise timestamp. Without high accuracy mode, you won’t get the real GNSS data you need, so don’t skip this part!

Next, you’ll need an app that can show you raw GNSS data, because regular apps like Google Maps don’t display this detailed info. Head to the Google Play Store and search for apps like “GPS Test” or “GNSS Status & Toolbox”—most of these are free and easy to use. Once you download one, open it up and give it permission to access your location; that’s key for it to connect to the satellites and pull in the timestamp data.

Now, wait a minute or two for the app to lock onto satellites. If you’re inside, you might need to move near a window or step outside, since walls can block the satellite signals. Once it’s connected, you’ll see a bunch of data: how many satellites it’s linked to, their signal strength, and somewhere in the menu (look for tabs like “Satellites” or “Raw Data”) you’ll find the GNSS timestamp. It might be labeled “GPS Time” or “GNSS Time,” and it’ll look like a long number or a specific date and time that’s synced perfectly with the satellites.

If you want to save or use this timestamp, many of these apps let you copy it to your clipboard, export the data as a file, or even share it with friends for a group project. For example, if you’re doing a science experiment that needs exact timing of a location-based event, this timestamp is way more reliable than just checking your phone’s clock. Just remember that the more satellites your phone connects to, the more accurate the timestamp will be—so patience is key when waiting for that satellite lock!

Oh, and one last thing: Don’t worry if the timestamp looks a little different from your phone’s regular time sometimes. GNSS time doesn’t account for leap seconds like our regular civil time does, but most apps will show you both the raw GNSS time and a converted version that matches your local time zone if you need it. That way, you can use whichever one fits what you’re working on, whether it’s a school project or just satisfying your curiosity about how satellite tech works.

prompt: Write a description for the Pixel 3A smartphone.
response:
"Unveiled in May 2019, the Google Pixel 3A redefined the mid-range smartphone market, proving that flagship-caliber photography and a premium software experience didn’t have to come with a flagship price tag. Positioned as the accessible sibling to the high-end Pixel 3, the 3A targeted everyday users who prioritized camera quality, clean software, and reliable performance without breaking the bank—and it delivered on every front, leaving a lasting legacy as one of the most influential mid-range phones of its era.

Starting with its design, the Pixel 3A opts for a durable polycarbonate unibody that feels surprisingly solid in the hand, despite its affordable materials. Available in three eye-catching hues—Just Black, Clearly White, and the fan-favorite Purple-ish—a matte finish resists fingerprints and gives the phone an understated, modern look. At 147 grams, it’s lightweight and compact, with a 5.6-inch screen that balances usability with one-handed comfort. The rear features a centered fingerprint sensor (fast and accurate, even with wet fingers), a single circular camera lens flanked by a LED flash, and the iconic Google logo. Up front, a small notch houses the 8MP selfie camera, with thin bezels framing the OLED display for an immersive yet uncluttered feel.

The 5.6-inch 1080p OLED display is a standout for its price range. Unlike many mid-range phones of the era that relied on LCD panels, the Pixel 3A’s OLED delivers deep, inky blacks, vibrant color reproduction, and excellent contrast ratios, making streaming movies, browsing photos, and reading in low light a pleasure. Google’s adaptive brightness algorithm is finely tuned, adjusting seamlessly to bright sunlight and dim indoor environments without being overly aggressive, while the 18:9 aspect ratio fits more content on the screen without feeling stretched.

But the Pixel 3A’s true claim to fame is its camera system—a single 12.2MP rear sensor identical to the one in the flagship Pixel 3, paired with Google’s industry-leading computational photography software. This combination turned the mid-range phone into a low-light photography powerhouse, thanks to Night Sight, a feature that captured bright, detailed images in near darkness without the harsh washout of a flash. Whether you were photographing a city skyline at dusk or a candlelit dinner, Night Sight produced sharp, noise-free photos that outperformed even more expensive phones with multiple lenses. Other flagship-level features included Portrait Mode, which created professional-looking depth effects with accurate edge detection; Top Shot, which automatically selected the best frame from a burst to avoid closed eyes or awkward expressions; and Super Res Zoom, which used machine learning to zoom in on subjects without losing detail. The 8MP front camera held its own too, with Portrait Mode for selfies and a Group Selfie feature that widened the frame to fit more friends in the shot.

Under the hood, the Pixel 3A packs a Qualcomm Snapdragon 670 processor, 4GB of RAM, and 64GB of non-expandable storage. While the Snapdragon 670 is a mid-range chip, Google’s stock Android software—free of bloatware and optimized for efficiency—ensured smooth performance for daily tasks. Multitasking between social media apps, streaming services, and web browsers felt effortless, and even light gaming (like *Candy Crush* or *Among Us*) ran without lag. For power users who demanded intensive gaming or heavy video editing, the 3A might have struggled, but for the vast majority of users, it was more than capable.

Software was another major selling point. The Pixel 3A launched with Android 9 Pie and received three full years of OS and security updates—an unprecedented commitment for a mid-range phone at the time, when most competitors offered only one or two years of support. This meant users enjoyed the latest Android features (like Dark Mode, Gesture Navigation, and Privacy Dashboard) long after launch, keeping the phone feeling fresh and secure. Stock Android’s clean, intuitive interface allowed for easy customization, with no pre-installed apps cluttering the home screen.

Battery life was reliable, with a 3000mAh battery that easily lasted a full day of moderate use—including streaming an hour of video, browsing social media for several hours, and taking dozens of photos. Google’s Adaptive Battery feature learned users’ app habits, reducing power to infrequently used apps to extend runtime. When the battery did run low, 18W fast charging provided a 50% charge in just 30 minutes, though wireless charging was notably absent (a trade-off for the lower price point).

In the years since its launch, the Pixel 3A has left a lasting legacy. It shattered the myth that great photography required a high-end price tag, pushing other manufacturers to invest in computational photography for their mid-range lines. For budget-conscious users who valued camera quality and a pure Android experience, the Pixel 3A wasn’t just a good phone—it was a revelation, proving that sometimes, smart software and targeted innovation matter more than cutting-edge hardware."

prompt: What is inside Shinto shrines? Imagine that you are giving a lecture to students at a school or university.
response:
Good morning, everyone. Today we’re going to explore the inner workings of Shinto shrines—spaces that are far more than architectural landmarks; they’re sacred hubs where humans connect with the kami, the divine spirits central to Shinto belief. Let’s walk through the key areas you’ll encounter once you step beyond the iconic torii gate.

First, after purifying your hands and mouth at the temizuya (stone basin just inside the shrine grounds), you’ll move toward the core structures. Let’s start with the most revered space:

*The Honden: The Sacred Heart of the Shrine*  
This is the innermost, most secluded part of the shrine, where the kami is believed to reside. Unlike other areas, the Honden is almost never open to the general public—only high-ranking shrine priests may enter to perform daily rituals, such as offering fresh water, rice, or sake to the kami. The physical representation of the kami, called a shintai, is kept here; this could be a polished mirror, a sword, a stone, or even a natural object like a tree branch. For example, if you ever visit [local shrine name], you’ll notice the Honden is tucked behind layers of wooden fences and gates, its simple, traditional design a stark reminder of its sacred purpose. It’s a space of quiet reverence, designed to honor the kami’s privacy and divine status.

Next, we have the area that acts as a bridge between mortal visitors and the secluded Honden:

*The Heiden: Mediator Between Humans and the Divine*  
The Heiden is the hall of offerings, where priests present gifts to the kami on behalf of the community. These offerings might include seasonal fruits, rice cakes, or even monetary donations. While visitors can’t enter the Heiden themselves, they can often see it from a distance, especially during festivals. During [annual festival date] at many shrines, the Heiden becomes the center of activity: priests chant norito (Shinto prayers), perform ceremonial dances, and present elaborate offerings to thank the kami for blessings like good harvests or safe travels. It’s here that the gap between our world and the divine narrows, allowing our gratitude and requests to reach the kami.

Finally, let’s talk about the space that’s often the first point of contact for visitors:

*The Shamusho: Administrative and Welcoming Hub*  
Located near the shrine entrance, the Shamusho serves as both the shrine’s office and a welcoming center for guests. Here, you can purchase omamori (protective talismans for health, academic success, or safety), omikuji (fortune slips that reveal your luck for the year), or write a wish on an ema (wooden plaque) to hang up for the kami to see. The staff at the Shamusho are usually well-versed in shrine history and etiquette, so don’t hesitate to ask questions. Some shrines even offer [traditional purification ritual workshop] here, where you can learn to perform temizu and other basic rituals under the guidance of a trained priest. It’s the perfect starting point for any shrine visit, blending practicality with spiritual connection.

Before we wrap up, remember that every shrine is unique—some are small, family-run sites in rural villages, while others are grand complexes like Ise Jingu. But no matter their size, they all share these core elements that reflect Shinto’s focus on harmony between humans, nature, and the divine.

Are there any questions about what we’ve covered today?

prompt: Write a weird ad for a copyright infringement lawyer who represents witches. Use only lowercase letters.
response:
<<spell copyright lawyer: we turn cease-and-desists into frog spawn>>

tired of that basic suburban witch stealing your signature "hex the nosy neighbor" incantation and selling it as a printable on etsy? fed up with warlocks passing off your broomstick levitation enchantment as their own at the annual coven summit? did a rival coven copy your cauldron’s secret three-moon simmer sequence and now their potions are outselling yours at the midnight farmers’ market?

you need a lawyer who speaks your language—literally. i don’t just know the federal copyright act; i can recite the 17th-century grimoire of intellectual property curses from memory. no stuffy conference rooms here: we meet in a hidden hollow under the old oak, where the coffee’s brewed with wormwood and the legal pads are made of pressed blackberry leaves.

here’s what i do for you:
- subpoena the spirit of the 16th-century witch who invented your spell’s core structure to testify via ouija board (they’re great at calling out copycats)
- turn the opposing counsel’s cease-and-desist letter into a swarm of fireflies that only blink insults at them
- negotiate settlements in bat guano, moondew, or first dibs on the next harvest of nightshade (no boring cash required)
- file a counterclaim for "emotional distress via spell dilution" when your once-exclusive curse becomes a viral tiktok sound
- seal court records with a binding charm so no muggle judge ever finds out you used a love spell to win over the jury

warning: i don’t represent witches who steal spells (that’s a curse-worthy offense, and i’ll hex you myself if you lie about it). also, if you show up with a broomstick that’s been enchanted by a copycat, i’ll make you clean my cauldron for a week as a lesson.

contact me by leaving a jar of fermented apple cider under the third stone to the left of the old cemetery gate at midnight. include a lock of your hair and a note describing the stolen spell in rhyming couplets. no emails—muggles hack those, and i don’t have time to hex every spam bot that finds my address.

last month, i got a witch’s signature love potion recipe back from a warlock who’d been selling it at ren faires. the settlement? he had to polish her broomstick every full moon for a year, and his familiar (a very sassy raven) now brings her fresh berries every sunday.

don’t let spell thieves get away with it. your incantations are your art—protect them with someone who knows magic and the law. (and if all else fails, we can turn the thief’s spellbook into a pile of slugs. no refunds on the slugs, though.)

prompt: How can you get to know someone on a deep level in a romantic relationship? The answer should involve the topic of vulnerability.
response:
To get to know someone on a deep level in a romantic relationship vulnerability is the foundation that unlocks true connection. Start by practicing intentional self-vulnerability beyond surface-level small talk. Share your quiet fears the moments you felt inadequate or the dreams you’ve hesitated to voice because you worried they might seem silly or too big. When you open up without pretense you signal to your partner that the relationship is a safe space where they won’t be judged for showing their own soft edges.

Create regular low-pressure moments to dive into deeper conversations instead of only relying on casual check-ins. This could be during a quiet walk after dinner while sitting together before bed or on a weekend trip where distractions are minimal. Ask open-ended questions that invite vulnerability rather than yes-or-no answers. For example instead of asking “Did you have a good childhood?” try “What’s a memory from your childhood that still affects how you see the world today?”

Practice active and non-reactive listening when your partner shares. Resist the urge to fix their problems immediately or compare their experiences to your own. Instead validate their feelings by saying things like “That sounds like it was really hard for you” or “I can see why that matters so much to you.” When they feel heard and accepted they’ll be more likely to keep opening up over time.

Embrace moments of discomfort together. Vulnerability can feel scary so it’s normal for either of you to hold back at times. If your partner seems hesitant don’t push them but let them know you’re there when they’re ready. Similarly if you feel nervous about sharing something acknowledge that feeling out loud. Saying “I’m a little scared to talk about this but I trust you enough to try” can deepen the connection and encourage mutual vulnerability.

Finally follow through on the trust you build. If your partner shares something private honor that confidence by not discussing it with others or using it against them in arguments. Consistency in being a safe and reliable person will make vulnerability feel less risky and more rewarding for both of you. Over time these acts of mutual vulnerability will weave a deep understanding of each other’s core selves that goes beyond surface attraction and creates a lasting romantic bond.

prompt: Can you write a rap?
response:
**Verse 1**  
Streetlights bleed amber over cracked concrete,  
Coffee steam curls slow where the cold meets heat,  
Notebook pages crumpled with the lines I couldn’t keep,  
Voice in my head saying “quit” but my heart’s got a beat,  
Used to hide my rhymes in the back of a drawer,  
Scared the world would laugh at the words I adored,  
Now I spit ’em loud where the concrete floors roar,  
Every stutter, every pause, every scar I ignore,  
They say success is a ladder, but mine’s got loose rungs,  
Climbed with broken nails when the doubt came in throngs,  
Hustle’s not a hashtag, it’s the dawn before dawn,  
When the city’s still sleeping and my pen’s still drawn.  

**Chorus**  
Yeah, we build from the dust, we rise from the ash,  
Every word’s a brick, every bar’s a crash,  
Against the walls they built to keep us in the past,  
We don’t chase the glow, we light our own path,  
No handouts, no shortcuts, just the grind in my bones,  
Every verse is a vow, every flow is a throne,  
We don’t need the crown to know we’re not alone,  
This is for the ones who’ve ever felt unknown.  

**Verse 2**  
Used to ride the bus, pen in hand, window fogged,  
Writing lines ’bout the dreams that the system robbed,  
Kids in the hood with the fire but no match,  
Teachers said “stick to the plan” but I tore up the batch,  
Now they see me on stages, but they don’t see the nights,  
Sleeping on couches, eating ramen, fighting the blight,  
Of self-doubt that creeps when the crowd’s out of sight,  
But I hold onto the words that kept me upright,  
They love the shine now, but they hated the grit,  
Said my flow was too rough, my story too split,  
But I turned the cracks into cracks they can’t fix,  
Every wound’s a verse, every scar’s a mix,  
Of the pain and the passion that keeps me awake,  
When the moon’s high and the stakes are at stake.  

**Bridge**  
Now I walk through the streets where I used to hide,  
Kids with notebooks asking me how to survive,  
I tell ’em “write the truth, let the lies fall aside,  
Your voice is your power, don’t let it be denied,”  
’Cause the world don’t need another copy of a copy,  
They need the raw, the real, the ones who don’t stop me,  
From spitting the truth that the suits try to top me,  
This is for the ones who refuse to be forgotten.  

**Outro**  
Streetlights bleed amber over cracked concrete,  
Coffee steam curls slow where the cold meets heat,  
Notebook pages filled with the lines I won’t keep,  
Voice in my head saying “go” and my heart’s got a beat,  
We build from the dust, we rise from the ash,  
Every word’s a brick, every bar’s a crash,  
Against the walls they built to keep us in the past,  
We light our own path, we make it last.

response:
# "Long-Lost Nephew Scam Rap"
(Beat: Lo-fi hip-hop with a silly horn riff)

Yo, it’s 2 a.m., I’m in my PJs, bowl of Cheerios  
Spoon mid-air, phone rings—unknown, so I pick it up, yo  
Voice on the line: thick accent, smooth as palm wine  
Says, “Hello, my friend—you are the long-lost nephew of the Nigerian king, divine!”

I blink, I yawn, say, “Bro, you got the wrong guy, I’m just a regular schmuck”  
He says, “No, no—your great-great-aunt was the king’s secret lover, no luck?  
Wait, no—your great-great-uncle was the royal treasurer, loyal and true  
He hid $50 million under a baobab tree, just for you!”

**[Scammer’s Ridiculous Pitch (Highlighted for Maximum Absurdity)]**  
“Government froze the funds, locked in a vault so secure  
We need $2,000 to unlock it—then you’ll be rich, no more poor!  
Wire the cash to this account: ‘Royal Unlock Services, Lagos’  
No tricks, no lies—you’ll be sipping champagne on a yacht, no more lagos!  
I swear on the king’s crown, this is 100% legit, no fraud  
You’ll never have to work again—just sit back, relax, and applaud!”

I snort, Cheerios fly out my nose, say, “Hold up, let’s fact-check this, chief  
First off, baobabs don’t grow in my grandma’s family tree, believe me  
Second, $2k? I can’t even afford my monthly pizza delivery fee  
You think I got that kind of dough to throw at a scam, buddy? Please!  
Wait, one question—does the king have a pet python? I’ve always wanted one  
Can I name him Kevin? He’d be my new best friend, son!”

He stutters, he sputters, says, “This is not a joke! We need the cash right now!”  
I say, “Chill, prince—let’s negotiate: I’ll give you $5 if you sing me a cow  
Moo like a Nigerian cow, loud and proud, no shame  
Then maybe I’ll consider your little money game!”

He yells, “You’re wasting my time! I have other marks to fool!”  
I say, “Wait, wait—can I get a signed autograph from the king, cool?  
Maybe a royal robe with my name on it, stitched in gold thread?  
Or a lifetime supply of jollof rice? That’s the real bread!”

Click—he hangs up, and I hear a faint “You’re an idiot!” in the background  
I put the phone down, finish my Cheerios, wipe my mouth, no sound  
Think to myself, “Man, scammers these days have no creativity  
They need to step up their game, get better lines, more sensitivity!”

Chorus (x2):  
Oh, I’m the long-lost nephew of the Nigerian king  
Got a call at 2 a.m., saying my luck’s about to sing  
But I know it’s a scam, so I’m gonna mess with this guy  
‘Til he hangs up screaming, asking why, why, why!

Outro:  
Yo, so moral of the story: don’t wire cash to a stranger on the line  
‘Cause the only thing you’ll get is an empty wallet and a whine  
Stay woke, stay silly, don’t fall for the fake royal pitch  
‘Cause the real treasure’s my bowl of Cheerios, and that’s the realest switch!  
*Mic drop.*
